citing_paper_authors: Sean, Igo | Ellen, Riloff
raw_text: (Kozareva et al, 2008) proposed the use of a doubly-anchored hyponym pattern anda graph to represent the links between hyponym occurrences in these patterns. Our work builds upon Turney? s work on semantic orientation (Turney, 2002) and synonym learning (Turney, 2001), in which he used a PMI-IRalgorithm to measure the similarity of words and phrases based on Web queries
clean_text: (Kozareva et al, 2008) proposed the use of a doubly-anchored hyponym pattern and a graph to represent the links between hyponym occurrences in these patterns.

citing_paper_authors: Zornitsa, Kozareva | Eduard, Hovy
raw_text: Potentially, one can explore all recursive pattern variations when learning a relation and compare their yield, however this study is beyond the scope of this paper. We are particularly interested in the usage of recursive patterns for the learning of semantic relations not only because it is a novel method, but also because recursive patterns of the DAP fashion are known to: (1) learn concepts with high precision compared to singly-anchored pat terns (Kozareva et al, 2008), (2) use only one seed instance for the discovery of new previously unknown terms, and (3) harvest knowledge with minimal supervision
clean_text: We are particularly interested in the usage of recursive patterns for the learning of semantic relations not only because it is a novel method, but also because recursive patterns of the DAP fashion are known to: (1) learn concepts with high precision compared to singly-anchored pat terns (Kozareva et al, 2008), (2) use only one seed instance for the discovery of new previously unknown terms, and (3) harvest knowledge with minimal supervision.

raw_text: This leads to the discovery of additional basic-level terms or in stances, which are then recycled in turn to discover new intermediate concepts, and so on. Consequently, we can compare the results produced by the first iteration of our algorithm (be fore intermediate concepts are learned) to those of (Kozareva et al, 2008) for the Animal and Peoplecategories, and then compare again after 10 bootstrapping iterations of intermediate concept learning
clean_text: Consequently, we can compare the results produced by the first iteration of our algorithm (before intermediate concepts are learned) to those of (Kozareva et al, 2008) for the Animal and People categories, and then compare again after 10 bootstrapping iterations of intermediate concept learning.

raw_text: Kozareva et al (2008) test their approach on relatively simple and objective categories like states, countries (both 836closed sets), singers and fish (both open, the for mer more so than the latter), but not on complex categories in which members are tied both to a general category, like food, and to a stereotypical property, like sweet (Veale and Hao, 2007)
clean_text: Kozareva et al (2008) test their approach on relatively simple and objective categories like states, countries (both closed sets), singers and fish (both open, the former more so than the latter), but not on complex categories in which members are tied both to a general category, like food, and to a stereotypical property, like sweet (Veale and Hao, 2007).
